results.title: Hearts in Atlantis
results.creator_credit: Kerry Heysen, Castle Rock Entertainment, NPV Entertainment, Village Roadshow Pictures and Scott Hicks
results.brief_description: A nostalgic film set in small town America of the 1960s about maturation and the loss of innocence. Bobby is an eleven-year-old boy feeling the stigma of being from a financially strapped one-parent family. One summer a mysterious boarder Ted Brautigan (Anthony Hopkins) comes to live in the upstairs part of the house and wins over Bobby, if not his suspicious mother, Liz. It is gradually revealed that Ted has psychic powers and sinister men in dark suits are pursuing him. Bobby, in need of a father figure, is drawn into Ted’s confidence, working for him, and absorbing Ted’s wisdom. Ted assists Bobby with difficult life matters - his first kiss, trust in others, and lessons in disappointment. Structured as a flashback, “Hearts in Atlantis” has a tone not unlike a darkly themed episode of “The Wonder years.” Hicks peppers a pedestrian screenplay, laden with symbolic diatribes, with 60s hits, an expressive score, and an eye for period detail. Hope Davis puts in an understated performance as Liz - a woman who struggles with her financial situation, whilst fending off her lecherous boss. Directed by Scott Hicks (Shine, Snow falling on cedars).

results.title: Hearts and minds
results.brief_description: The evolution of civilization throughout the world is contrasted with the lack of development, the exploitation, and agony of Vietnam, through the ages. Problems of power, human rights, domestic politics, national prestige, and development of economy are so involved with fallible political processes; “Peace”, “Ceasefire”, “Negotiation”, become meaningless re-iterations. Petty’s first film comprising footage that he shot on a trip to Vietnam combined with animation of some of his newspape cartoons. Accompanied with music by George Dreyfus, the narrative builds to a strong anti-war statement.

results.title: Heartlands: diversity or dust
results.brief_description: Narrated by Richard Bawden this episode looks at a small group of farmers who have developed a meaningful relationship with the land. When these farmers arrived on their selections in Western Australia in the fifties, they were required by the Lands Department to clear a certain percentage of their land. Initially, believing that opening up the land and growing wheat was a worthy enterprise, they readily cleared the native bush. As time went on some of them realised that this practice was doing great damage, increasing salinity and rendering the land barren. Gradually they developed an understanding of the balance of the natural environment, and realised that the ‘empty’ land they had settled contained plant species of enormous diversity. Led by Veronica Kingdon, the farmers conducted and won a campaign against the Lands Department. Their political lobbying has stopped all major land clearing in the state. Their efforts also contributed to the establishment of Fitzgerald National Park, one of the richest botanical regions in the world. Now self-taught botanists, geologists, nature photographers and seed collectors they conduct a wildflower show each year to raise awareness about plant diversity in the region. Their efforts are a model for showing how a small group of dedicated individuals can bring about profound change.

results.title: Heartlands with Dean Graetz : water
results.brief_description: Other civilisations have ignored the warning signs that Australia is currently receiving regarding salinity. Salinity poses a major ecological problem to Australia in the forms of land erosion along the coastline, and destroying food and water supplies inland. It has occurred because we have taken too much from the land and the natural barriers to salinity have broken down. This documentary interviews a Murray River farmer, attempts to explain why the situation has occurred, and searches for a solution for the future.

results.brief_description: A recollection on the days when, as a child, dust storms would assail the buildings and school children would be sent home leads the adult Dean Graetz on an exploration of what percentage of Australia’s land can support its inhabitants, what has been lost, and why its happened.

results.title: Heartlands with Dean Graetz : arid
results.brief_description: This program looks at Australia’s arid heartland, an area largely ignored by the residents of the less arid coastline. The situation has been caused by government lack of control over crown land and over- grazing by pastoralists. Significantly, it is the result of white mans’ failure to recognise the limitations of the land. The program offers two alternatives; act now and save what’s left or continue as before and further destroy the productivity of the land.

results.title: Heartlands : the promised land
results.brief_description: The highly populated Eastern seaboard of Australia is subject to enormous pressures. The demands of agriculture and the urban sprawl have led to poor land management and unsustainable use of the land. This program looks at land use on the Sunshine Coast of Queensland as an example of the problems caused by bad planning. It focuses on a number of individuals who have envisaged new and more sustainable ways of inter-relating with the land they live and work on. They all emphasise that breaking the cycle of stress on the land requires radical shifts in the way we think. Max Lindiger promotes the creation of small self-sustaining communities, rather than ever-expanding urban sprawl as a way of reducing suburban isolation and costly food transportation. Margaret Skelton and her husband have turned to permaculture as a way of efficiently using their small block of land. Permaculture is an intensive, organic agricultural system which conserves natural resources and produces a surplus of food. Sugar has been a staple crop of the Nambour region for many years. However the heavy use of chemicals have depleted the land which, since the decline of the sugar industry, is being sold off for real estate. In order to retain the land for agriculture one farmer has turned to organic methods of farming.

results.title: Heartlands : taking control
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Tim Clark and Matthew Flanagan
results.brief_description: These are five programs from the ‘Heartlands” series about people and how they interact with the environment. It provides examples of people who are actively helping the environment, some on an individual level and some on a global scale, but the principle by which all of these people operate is that every individual can change the world if they start with themselves. We must learn from our living experiences, or else we are compelled to keep making the same mistakes - we live on a single planet with limited resources and we are all responsible for how they are used. Population and consumption cannot be sustained at current usage levels - we need to get back to the principles of living within our means in order to affect change for the better in the environment.

results.title: Heartlands : minerals
results.brief_description: This programme, presented by Dean Graetz, looks at mining in Australia and the impact and social costs the depletion of ore resources has on mining communities. Changes to mining methods are also covered, with the industry not needing to hire as many people due to the technological advancements in the field. Dean Graetz also highlights the differences in attitudes towards agricultural and pastoral land and mining, stressing that agriculture will sustain us in the future, and not mining, which is a finite resource.

results.title: Heartlands : good work
results.brief_description: Richard Bawden introduces a man with a remarkable solution to Australia’s unemployment figure. Originally a migrant from Italy but now an Australian citizen, he has a vision for a new Australian society based on people as its natural resource. He believes that Australia’s reliance on developing its natural resources has been to the detriment of her people. He has instituted a job creation scheme at Murdoch University in Western Australia based on his vision.
